title-group.article-title: Tonal vibration suppression with a model-free control method

contrib-group.aff: State Key Laboratory of Mechanical Systems and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Zhiyi Zhang, State Key Laboratory of Mechanical Systems and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, People’s Republic of China. Email: chychang@sjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: A novel model-free control method for actively suppressing tonal structural vibration is investigated through numerical simulation and experiment. The model-free control method is established on the least-mean-squares-based adaptive feedback control principle, and an instrumental mechanism for adjusting the controller parameters is proposed to guarantee convergence of the algorithm. In the numerical verification of the model-free control method, a shaft–plate system is used to derive a lightly damped dynamic model, which is obtained by frequency response function synthesis, while in the experiment a shaft–cylinder system with time-varying dynamics is applied to evaluate the control system with respect to its potential in vibration control. In the control system, an electromagnetic actuator mounted on the shaft is enforced with the model-free control method to cancel vibration induced by the disturbance forces. Simulation results have demonstrated that the model-free control method is able to guarantee stability in the presence of changes in the disturbances and plant dynamics and that it is effective in attenuating vibration of the system. Experimental results have also demonstrated that the control system can tranquilize vibration of the shaft and suppress tonal vibrations in the shell effectively, but variation in the control channel should be sufficiently slow that the algorithm can complete its adaptation in time.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Ship propulsion systems transmit vibration directly to hull structures and they are usually the principal source of structural vibration. Vibration control strategies associated with shaft systems have been studied for decades and investigations have been focused on reducing vibration of the shaft system and force transmission by inserting auxiliary systems to change the dynamics of the original system.1–5 Experiments concerning shaft dynamics and vibration control were carried out years ago.4–7 Active control of vibration of the shaft system with different actuation scenarios has been reported by Lewis et al.5 and Baz et al.6 The results obtained by Pan et al.7 revealed that the stiffness of the thrust bearing’s oil film varies in a wide range with the shaft revolution speed, which implies that the influence of the speed-dependent characteristics of the shaft system needs to be considered in active control of hull vibrations. However, it should be pointed out that active vibration control of the time-varying shaft system that is coupled with hull structures has not been investigated and the control method involved is not yet available.

Active control methods, such as velocity feedback control and optimal control, have already been applied to suppress vibrations induced by the shaft system.3–6 In these investigations, however, the control channel was treated as a time-invariant system. In fact, when the stiffness of the thrust bearing’s oil film changes in a wide range, the time-varying characteristics of the control channel have to be considered in the construction of active control strategies. Moreover, uncertainties also exist in the variation in the bearing stiffness. This unfortunately adds difficulties to the active vibration control because model identification for time-varying systems with uncertainties is an extremely difficult problem. At the same time, disturbances in the shaft system are mainly composed of harmonics, which demands that controllers have a narrowband disturbance rejection capability. For linear time-invariant systems under harmonic excitation, adaptive methods and other model-based methods, such as the filtered-x least-mean-squares and internal model principle techniques, can be used to cancel the disturbances.8–10 For time-varying systems, disturbance rejection is much more complicated,11–13 especially in the circumstance when no plant model is available, which renders even adaptive methods with online modelling incompetent. A promising method, namely self-optimizing narrowband interference cancelling, does not need modelling and has been demonstrated to be effective for time-varying first-order and second-order systems,14,15 but it still has to be improved for higher-order systems. Other methods without modelling have also been investigated.16–19

In this study, a shaft–plate model is utilized to derive a dynamic system for numerically investigating active vibration control in the presence of time-varying characteristics. The actuation force is along the shaft axis and a new model-free control (MFC) method is proposed to deal with time-varying harmonic excitation. This simple model is in fact as complicated as a real shaft–hull system from the viewpoint of verification of the control laws. An experimental shaft–cylinder model is established to explore the feasibility of the proposed active control system, which utilizes an actuator suspended on the shaft to absorb vibration of the shaft at the command of the MFC method. Discussion of this work is organized in six sections. A numerical model is presented in the second section. The MFC method and its simulation are given subsequently in the third section and fourth section respectively. The experimental system is briefly described in the first part of the fifth section, and the experimental results of the MFC method and tonal vibration suppression are presented in the second part of the fifth section. Finally, conclusions are drawn in the sixth section.

sec.title: A shaft–plate model for numerical investigation
sec.p: In this section, the frequency response functions (FRFs) associated with a shaft–plate model are briefly presented. The shaft–plate model is employed to represent a shaft–cylinder system, which is the major part of the experimental system presented in the fifth section. Although the shaft–plate model does not have a structure as complicated as that of the shaft–cylinder system, it has similar dynamics from the viewpoint of coupling between the longitudinal and the lateral vibrations; the shaft is supported on flexible structures through elastic coupling and subjected to longitudinal force disturbances. The dynamics of this simplified model are in fact sufficiently sophisticated that they can be used to investigate the MFC method for systems with varying dynamics. This is also necessary for verification of the active control strategies. Another reason is that mathematical modelling of the shaft–plate model is relatively easy to carry out. The shaft–plate coupled model is shown in Figure 1, in which the slender shaft is connected to the thin plate through two springs and one rigid joint. In this system, it is assumed, first, that the plate is simply supported and the displacements of the shaft occur only in the XOY¯ plane or the XOY plane, second, that the longitudinal sliding of the shaft is frictionless and rotation of its spring-tagged end is unconstrained and, third, that deflections of the shaft and the plate are sufficiently small that the system behaves linearly. Under excitation of the disturbance force F, as shown in Figure 1, the shaft–plate coupled system will vibrate and, in particular, the shaft will vibrate in both the longitudinal direction and the lateral direction. In this study, modelling of the vibration of this system is based on synthesis of the FRFs.

sec.p: Figure 2 depicts the external and internal forces as well as the vibration displacements. The shaft and the plate are viewed as two independent components and they are assembled together by joints at the interfaces, as shown in the figure. The lateral displacements of points 1 and 2 are related by the stiffness ks of the lateral spring, and the longitudinal displacements of points 4 and 5 are related by the stiffness kt of the longitudinal spring. Synthesis is carried out with the FRFs of the two components. The parameters of the system are listed in Table 1. Simulation of the control method will be based on such a specific system but without any loss of generality. It should be noted that ks=4 × 105 N/m is determined so that the spring is neither too soft nor too rigid although the stiffness can be theoretically smaller or larger than, say, 104 N/m or 107 N/m.

sec.title: Model-free adaptive feedback control
sec.p: To counteract the influence of the tonal disturbing force F, the control force Fa is required to react to the error response at point 5, as defined in the second section. However, the FRF of the control channel is dependent on the stiffness kt, which demands a controller to accommodate any variation in the control channel caused by the varying kt. Therefore, a model-based control method needs first to identify the kt -dependent dynamic model and then to establish a control law that takes into account variations. Considering the variations in the stiffness and the frequency of the disturbing force F, it is not easy to find an appropriate model to describe the control channel and to update it online. Here, an MFC method is proposed to replace the conventional model based control method. This MFC method, which is formed on the basis of earlier investigations,9,20 incorporates the adaptive feedback principle based on the least-mean-squares (LMS) technique and an instrumental adaptation mechanism, referred to as the X adjustment. Figure 5 is the diagram of the control system, where dk is the disturbance, ek is the error signal, H(z) is the control channel and W(z) the controller. In this system, tracking filters are employed to retrieve the harmonic signals at those frequencies that are multiples of the fundamental frequency. The centre frequencies of these filters are adjusted according to the measured fundamental frequency of the tonal disturbance.

caption.p: Model-free adaptive feedback control with tracking filters.
LMS: least mean squares.

It should be noted that the saturation unit in Figure 5 is described by the sigmoid function and it is used to restrict otherwise unceasing growth of signals in the feedback loop. The problem with equation (4) is that μ needs to change its sign because of the uncompensated dynamics of the control channel. The simplest way to change the sign of μ is to switch it manually by observing the variation in the error signal amplitude when the control is turned on. In this study, the X-adjustment mechanism is applied to adjust the sign of μ and the threshold of f(u) automatically. This mechanism was first presented by Zhang et al.22 and its effectiveness was demonstrated by numerical simulation. It is recast here after some improvements as

where r(t)=2E¯(t) (where E¯(t)=(1/Δ)∫t−Δtε2(τ)dτ and Δ=2π/ω), r0 is a threshold value for r(t), κ(t) is a square wave (i.e. κ(t)=1or−1), ca,cb>0 and β=α+(2/Δ)∫t−Δt|v(τ)|dτ (where α>0 and v(t) is the filtered controller output). In equation (5), E¯(t) is defined as a measure of the signal intensity, and [1/r(t)][dr(t)/dt] (which is deduced from E¯(t)) is associated with the derivative of E¯(t) with respect to the time t. In fact, suppose that ε(t)=r(t)sin(ωt) and that r(t) varies much more slowly than sin(ωt) (r(t) is the amplitude of ε(t)), then E¯(t)≈0.5r2(t) and the derivative of E¯(t) with respect to the time t is approximately r(t)[dr(t)/dt]. Therefore, the derivative will be negative as long as ε(t)=r(t)sin(ωt) decreases. This simple property can be used to adjust the sign of μ. However, r(t)[dr(t)/dt] implies that the derivative is heavily dependent on the amplitude of a specific signal. To reduce this dependence as much as possible, [1/r(t)][dr(t)/dt] is used to replace r(t)[dr(t)/dt]. Therefore, for a signal with an exponentially varying amplitude, [1/r(t)][dr(t)/dt] is a time-independent value. κ(t) in equation (5a) switches the sign of μ until dr(t)/dt<0 is achieved but prevents excessive alternation in order to guarantee convergence. Moreover, car(t)/(|dr(t)/dt|+cb) in equation (5b) accelerates the convergence of ε(t), and β in equation (5b) adjusts the threshold of the saturation unit in order to sustain a required magnitude of the control signal v(t).

sec.title: Simulation results
sec.p: Suppose that the frequency of the tonal disturbance force varies piecewise between 100Hz and 200Hz. By observing the diagrams in Figure 4, we can see that the phase is nearly reversed at resonant frequencies. The parameters of the controller used in the simulation are μ(0)=−1, r0=10−5, ca=5000, cb=1 and α=1. The sampling frequency is 1000 Hz. Figure 6 illustrates the results, which demonstrate that the response (Figure 6(f)) is controlled at the five discrete frequencies although the phase changes are nearly 180°. The curve of μ (Figure 6(c)) shows that it changes sign frequently at the initial stage of the frequency jump but, after a few steps of adaptation, μ can arrive at its correct value, i.e.+1 or −1. The switch of μ is determined by the oscillation of [1/r(t)][dr(t)/dt] (Figure 6(d)) around zero and the relatively large value of r(t) (Figure 6(e)). The frequency of the sign switch in fact depends on the proximity of a specific excitation frequency to lightly damped natural frequencies of the system, which determines the degree of influence of the lightly damped modes on the filtering of the error signals. For instance, the frequency 150Hz is close to one lightly damped mode, and the filtering with a tracking filter at 150Hz is thus disturbed strongly by the resonant mode. In essence, this difficulty is caused by the uncompensated dynamics of the control channel. Hence, heavy damping in the system is favourable to the implementation of MFC. When [1/r(t)][dr(t)/dt]<0 and r(t)>r0, car(t)/(|dr(t)/dt|+cb) (Figure 6(b)) sustains a high level so that r(t) can decrease quickly. Comparing Figure 6(e) with Figure 6(f), we can see that r(t) represents approximately the amplitude of the control error e(t).

sec.title: A shaft–cylinder system for experimental investigation
Configuration of the system
sec.p: The experimental system is shown in Figure 7. It is mainly composed of a cylindrical shell that is suspended on air springs, a shaft system, a loading device and a suspended shaker. The dimensions of the cylindrical shell are 15 m in length and 2 m in diameter. In the shaft system, the shaft of diameter 50 mm is supported by two rubber bearings and one thrust bearing, and it is connected with the motor through an elastic coupling. All the bearings are lubricated by water or oil. At the free end of the shaft, there is a rigid disc that is pushed by the loading device, and the thrust force is adjusted by the air pressure in the air springs. The shaker excites the loading device in the longitudinal direction, and the exerted dynamic force will induce vibration in the shaft and the cylindrical shell. On the shaft, there is also an electromagnetic inertial actuator near the thrust bearing, which is applied to counteract the influence of the shaking force. The actuator is able to rotate about the axis of the shaft owing to the ball bearings between it and the shaft, which allows it not to rotate together with the shaft although the shaft is driven by the motor. The reaction force created by the inertial mass controls vibration of the shaft by minimizing vibration at the thrust bearing according to control commands. An accelerometer is mounted at the thrust bearing’s support to measure the longitudinal vibration or error signal. Over 30 accelerometers are placed on the structure to measure the vibrations in the longitudinal, circumferential and normal directions (x, y and z respectively). Some of these transducers (point 17, point 20, point 24, point 27 and point 31) are shown in Figure 7.

caption.p: Configuration of the experimental system.

sec.title: Measurement and control results
sec.p: The FRFs between the longitudinal vibration response and the disturbance and control forces were measured first. The acceleration responses in the longitudinal direction were examined and found to have excellent linearity. Therefore, the FRFs can be measured through a broadband excitation, e.g. random excitation. The measured FRFs associated with the non-rotating shaft are plotted in Figure 8, in which Figure 8(a) is the FRF between the acceleration response at the thrust bearing (point 27) and the disturbance force while Figure 8(b) is the FRF between the acceleration response (point 27) and the excitation voltage input to the amplifier of the actuator. As shown in the figure, the two curves are similar, which agrees with the result in Figure 3. The discrepancy is caused by the dynamics of the amplifier and the actuator, which in fact have a few time delays in the responses. The resonance frequencies can be observed from the curves and they are around 23Hz, 50Hz, 77Hz, 95Hz, 99Hz, 136Hz and 140Hz. The first two frequencies correspond to the bending modes of the cylindrical shell (vibrating like a beam). The frequency 95Hz corresponds to the longitudinal vibration mode while 77Hz and 99Hz correspond to mixed-vibration modes that have longitudinal vibrations, bending vibrations and radial vibrations in the stiffened shell.

caption.p: Measured FRFs on excitation by (a) the shaker (response at point 27; voltage input) and (b) the actuator (response at point 27; disturbance force) (g = 9.8 m/s2).

sec.p: However, the FRFs will vary when the shaft rotates. Because of the squeezed oil film in the thrust bearing, which is formed by two relatively moving faces, the contact stiffness between the shaft and the thrust bearing changes with the shaft speed. Figure 9 gives the measured FRFs at different speeds, from which it can be seen that the FRF curves are shifted towards the low-frequency range and the variation is larger at lower speeds. This property indicates that the dynamics of the shaft system are dependent on the shaft speed or time varying as the speed changes continuously with time.

caption.p: Measured FRFs at different speeds (g = 9.8 m/s2).
FRF: frequency response function.

sec.p: Experiments were conducted to verify the efficacy of the MFC method. Shaking was carried out at the disc, as shown in Figure 7. The excitation frequencies were chosen in particular so that resonance of the system was provoked. In the experiment, different cases of active control were completed. In the first case, the shaft was not rotating and the excitation frequencies were 77Hz and 100Hz, which are two resonance frequencies. Using the control law given by equations (3) to (5) to suppress vibrations at the two frequencies simultaneously, we obtained the results shown in Figure 10, from which it can be seen that vibration at the thrust bearing is reduced at 77Hz and 100Hz but increases slightly over the rest of the frequency band, while vibration of the shell is reduced over the given frequency band after active control. Figure 11 gives the time histories of vibration at 95 Hz, from which we can observe the transient evolution of vibration cancellation when active control is turned on. After control, vibrations at the selected points are reduced almost to the same level.

caption.p: Before vibration control (red curves) and after vibration control (green curves) at 77 Hz and 100 Hz (g = 9.8 m/s2; reference = 1 unit): (a) thrust bearing (point 27); (b) shell surface (point 24); (c) inner plate (point 31); (d) shell surface (point 17).
PSD: power spectrum density.
Vibration control at 95 Hz. Control action is turned on at t = 3.5 s (g = 9.8 m/s2).

sec.p: In the second case, the shaft rotates and the resulting FRF of the control channel is shifted from that in the non-rotating case where an anti-resonance point at about 115Hz exists, as is shown in Figure 9. The shifted FRF does not have anti-resonance points over 110–120 Hz and as a result the feedback signal cannot be zero, which implies that vibration cancellation at these frequencies can be achieved without difficulty. Figure 12 shows that vibration at 117Hz is suppressed when the active control is turned on although the shaft is rotating at 50 r/min. Since the motor is running in this case, the spectra are different from those without excitation of the motor.

caption.p: Before vibration control (red curves) and after vibration control (green curves) at 117 Hz (shaft speed, 50 r/min; g = 9.8 m/s2; reference = 1 unit).
PSD: power spectrum density.

sec.p: The above experiments have not considered the influence of the changes in the dynamics of the control channel, and the adaptation mechanism given by equation (5) needs further verification when the phase–frequency curve is changed. However, by observing the curves in Figure 9, we can see that the phase changes due to the variation in the speed are not yet sufficiently large. For example, when the shaft speed varies from 50r/min to 200r/min, the phase change is within 90°, which cannot trigger an unstable adaptation. Therefore, we considered the third case where the excitation frequency varied in a wide range, covering the band for which the phase change is more than 90°. By shaking the shaft with a sweep-sine mode of excitation (i.e. the excitation frequency varies linearly from 80Hz to 150Hz in 16s) and counter-acting the shaft’s vibration according to equations (3) to (5), we obtained the results shown in Figure 13. It can be seen that vibration is attenuated over the given frequency band, but the performance around 95Hz is not as good as at other frequencies. The problem with equations (3) to (5) is that the rate of convergence is not sufficiently fast to accommodate the phase changes at certain frequencies, e.g. 95–100 Hz in this case.

caption.p: Before vibration control (red curves) and after vibration control (green curves) under sweep-sine excitation at 80–150 Hz (g = 9.8 m/s2; reference = 1 unit): (a) time histories (point 27); (b) spectra (point 27); (c) time histories (point 20); (d) spectra (point 20).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Active vibration control with an MFC method is discussed. The MFC method is proposed to control vibrations in the systems with time-varying characteristics, such as the propulsion systems in marine ships. The MFC method incorporates an LMS-based controller and an instrumental mechanism for adjusting the parameters of the controller. Investigation is conducted by numerical simulation and experiments. A numerical shaft–plate model is used to verify the MFC method and simulation results have demonstrated that the MFC algorithm is convergent and able to suppress structural vibration in the presence of variation in the disturbances. In the experiments, a shaft–cylinder system is used to verify the control system, in which an actuator suspended on the shaft absorbs the shaft’s vibration in response to the commands of the model-free controller. The measured FRFs demonstrated that the dynamics of the control channel are dependent on the shaft speed; the actuator enforced with the MFC algorithm is able to suppress tonal vibrations irrespective of whether the shaft is rotating, and vibration in the shell is attenuated when vibration at the thrust bearing is controlled. However, the problem with the adaptive method is its relatively slow adaptation to changes in the control channel, which may not guarantee a good control performance and therefore needs further improvement.
